abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Lake Victoria
            Environmental Management Project for Tanzania were as
            follows: the outcome was satisfactory, the sustainability
            was likely, the institutional development impact was
            substantial, and the Bank and borrower performance were both
            satisfactory. Lessons learned from the project: As is
            fitting for a project supporting acquisition of knowledge,
            many of the lessons learned are technical in nature.
            Interlinked national projects are vulnerable to failure of
            one of the partners, and must build in peer review and
            assistance, and safeguards in the event that these fail.
            Scientific research must be targeted, provide usable
            information for management decisions and be widely
            accessible. Regional projects necessitate greater emphasis
            on clarity of project objectives, monitorable frameworks, at
            multiple levels, and adequate mechanisms for governance. The
            Basin perspective is critical to address the key
            environmental issues of Lake Victoria. Capacity building has
            to address both current and projected gaps. Implementation
            in the future can be undertaken through governmental
            structures. Environmental benefits must be strongly linked
            to improved livelihoods for local people and communities.
            Good education of the public and parliamentarians is
            critical for long term sustainability and success.
